title: What's Risky Drinking?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: A beer or glass of wine after a hard day’s work. A glass of champagne to toast a special occasion. Many people drink alcohol when celebrating, socializing, or trying to relax. But when is a drink just a harmless drink? When is it best not to drink at all? And what are “risky” drinking and binge drinking ?

sections.heading: What If I Drink Very Little -- on Occasion?
content: It’s important to remember that alcohol is a drug. There is no health benefit from drinking alcohol. The U.S. Surgeon General warns that moderate consumption of alcohol (two drinks a day) raises the risk for cancers of the mouth, throat breast, colorectum, esophagus, voice box, and liver. It has also been linked to an increased risk of stroke .
You should avoid alcohol completely if you’re:
bullets: Planning to drive a vehicle or operate any kind of machinery
Taking any medicines that interact with alcohol
Living with a medical condition that could be made worse by alcohol
Pregnant or are trying to have a baby

sections.heading: What’s a ‘Serving’ of Alcohol?
content: You can’t tell how much alcohol is in your drink by the amount of liquid in your glass or bottle.
In the United States, one “standard” drink has about 14 grams of pure alcohol. This is generally the amount in:

Different types or brands of beer, wine, and spirits can contain varying amounts of alcohol. For example, some kinds of beer, like microbrews, have more than 5% alcohol. That means if you drink a beer that’s 10% alcohol, you’re consuming two “standard” drinks, not one (since it’s twice the amount of alcohol).
bullets: 12 ounces of regular beer -- that’s a regular can (usually 5% alcohol)
5 ounces of wine (usually 12% alcohol)
1.5 ounces of distilled spirits (usually about 40% alcohol)

content: There are weekly “upper limits” for healthy adults:

sections.heading: What’s Binge Drinking?
content: It means you have a pattern of drinking large amounts of alcohol in short periods of time. According to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism , it involves drinking enough alcohol to raise your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) to 0.08% or higher. The rough estimates this are:

This is why you have to be careful on special occasions. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) considers drinking five or more “standard” drinks on the same occasion on at least 1 day in the past 30 days as binge drinking.
bullets: Men: Five or more “standard” drinks in 2 hours
Women: Four or more “standard” drinks in 2 hours

sections.heading: What’s 'Risky' Drinking?
content: It means you drink too much, too often. In general, for men, this means having more than four drinks on any given day. For women, it means having three drinks within that same time frame.

How much you drink and how often matters more than what type of alcohol you drink. Even if two people regularly have the same total amount of drinks in one week, their health consequences could be different. For example, having seven drinks in one night and not drinking the rest of the week is not the same as having one drink every night for a week. Even though the totals are the same, regularly drinking heavily and often is considered “risky.” Learn more: Does drinking everyday make you an alcoholic ?

sections.heading: What Does Risky Drinking Do to My Health?
content: Over time, it can damage your body. It can affect your liver , causing inflammation (alcoholic hepatitis). It could lead to scarring of your liver ( cirrhosis ), which can be life-threatening.
Risky drinking can also increase your risk of stroke, damage your heart muscle ( cardiomyopathy ), and increase your blood pressure . It also has been linked to several different kinds of cancer .
